history.content:
Took almost the same class load this semester (except Physics7A replaced CS100). My advice would be to go to/watch every CS170 lecture, fully absorb the textbook (which is pretty small actually), and attend all discussions. 170 is conceptually heavy more than anything. Understanding the homeworks is pivotal as well. The exams tended to ask about very conceptually difficult questions that reached beyond the presented material so having a full understanding is key to success.

CSw186 was actually very straightforward in the depth of the material. The homeworks (projects) could take between 10-20 hours and there are only 5 in the semester. Other than that, exams and quizzes were very self-contained. Lectures were informative and concise. The class also curved really well (~50% got A). 

I've heard CS100 is on par with difficulty somewhere between 61A and 61B. The material is usually not too intense and often interesting.

My general advice would be to manage your time very precisely. Do the homeworks and watch the lectures at regular times during the week. Keep aside time to take notes on the 170 textbook (which quite honestly is such a well written book, I have it in my backpack at all times). Being about a lecture ahead on the material would be the ideal place to be, especially for 170 since mastery of the concepts takes repeated exposure to some of the topics.

If you want the most out of your winter break studying, I would say cut the lecture and just dive straight into the textbook. Read through it and start doing the corresponding past discussions and homeworks for practice.

children.subject: Also make you sure you have enough time to get at least a moderate amount of exercise and sleep (and fun!) during the semester. Your health is more important than your classes.

^ I would disagree. Tbh just enjoy your winter break (treat yourself, you just declared! ) and have fun and exercise.  The classes you are taking are bound to be loads of work regardless if you prep or not (170 especially). You won’t have much time to yourself/to exercise so make sure you can do that now to make sure your health is in order. Especially when finals come around it’s gonna be very stressful (speaking from personal experience) so make sure you can prep for that and don’t flame out.
Also, create a study group. They could really help you learn material faster and keep you accountable with not giving up :)

Side note: 186 projects are not easy. Maybe #1 and #4 could take 5 hours, but 2, 3, and 5 are very difficult to debug and hard to find your errors, and many times, understand spec. Some people may find it easy and 10-20 hour doable, and yes,, class was curved really well, but those projects can take a long time. #1 took me 1 hour for all but one problem, and 3 hours overall. 4 took me 5-10. 2 took me 15-20. 3 and 5 took me a very long time as I had a tough time figuring spec out, and consequently, spent days debugging. Office hours, you’ll get helped once and it won’t be long. If you have a bug, especially for 3 and 5, chances are the TAs won’t find it. Conceptually, they can help you,  but if you’re stuck, piazza and friends will be your best bet.

I found midterms difficult because I also had 3 techs like you plan to. 186 midterms require a lot more knowledge than just basic lecture, projects, and discussion understanding.

maybe it’s an easy and decent workload and I’m an anomaly, but it was my most time consuming course last semester.

I don’t recommend studying over break unless it’s interview prep or projects for leisure/resume. You can definitely get an internship this summer.

Go to lectures, watch 186 lectures day they come out(easy to fall behind since it’s all online), go to discussions, especially 186 because the TAs are really good(they explain difficult concepts well), and start hw day they’re assigned. The idea is you’re less stressed if you are stuck on problem X on day 1 vs day 7. Also, you’ll have more time to work on problems if you start earlier. If you start missing one lecture here and there, with 3 techs, it will turn into 2, then 3, then 10 missed lectures and cramming won’t help you. You’ll probably have tons of times in which you’d rather go to office hours or work on a hw instead of lecture, don’t do that. I did and it really wasn’t good. I recovered and got good grades, but I didn’t have deep understanding of material that I preferred to have. And midterm weeks were tiring.

I had a month where each week I had: midterm, project, lab, hw due. That’s why it’s important to stay on top of work every week because you might encounter an overwhelming week and won’t have time to cram for another assignment.

You might be super fine and it won’t have a hard semester, but hope this helps!

history.content:
Hi! Happy holidays!

I am finally able to declare CS, and in these past semesters, I have been entirely focused on the classes that I needed to do well in order to declare (61A, 61B, and 70) at the expense of the other classes I was taking alongside them. Now that I will not feel the need to focus entirely on one class in one semester, I can now properly balance out my allocation of time toward all of the classes that I will be taking from now on. Next semester, I will be taking CS170, CS186, and CS100. 

Does anyone have any advice for optimally managing three techs in a semester or can someone point me to somewhere with such advice? I tried looking for some posts on here but could not find any.
history.subject: Any tips for doing well with three techs next semester?
